reviewText:
First and foremost, I backed this during Kickstarter because... well... it's historically the first African-themed Action RPG in the world. Made by a small studio based in Africa, no less. To be honest, I only expected to be involved in this to own a quaint and quirky little game in my collection. I mean, the Kickstarter was a success, sure, but it was only a marginal success with just enough funding to get this game through the door.

What I did NOT expect was a full-fledged powerhouse RPG with very strong cultural thematics and combat controls that AAA studios could learn a thing or two from.

I'm 3 hours in deep and I feel that I have barely scratched the surface of this game. The world seems huge and simple combos are pretty easy to pull off. I believe, with more practice, I could probably kill a strong enemy without it touching the ground after launching it into the air.

Now, for the criticisms; constructive, of course.

1) I've praised a lot about the combat because, outside of it, the controls need some improvement and the environment needs more interactivity. During the prologue phase, moving the good prince around was a chore as the analog stick was way too sensitive. Truth be told, I was expecting that kind of level of control throughout the game because my expectations wasn't way up there in the first place, expecially with a fledgling studio. I am pleasantly surprised that it got WAY better after the prince became a king and had a wardrobe change. I guess it's good to be the king and not wearing pants helped.

2) I'm not sure about the Francais dialogues but the English ones were suffering... a lot. I could still get what the characters were talking about but there was quite a handful of missing spaces and punctuations in the sentences. Loads of grammar mistakes as well. I understand that English is not their native tongue but it's not mine either so...

3) I only started to REALLY understand the level of detail and attention put into the combat mechanics after spending 2 hours in the game. Seriously, guys, a tutorial AFTER beating a boss character? I should be glad that you tried something different but... geez...

Anyway, get this game if you're into RPGs, Action RPGs, African culture & music, like to pull off sick combos, a Fighting Game enthusiast who wants to tinkle your toes in the RPG pool or an RPG afficionado who wants to try a little Street Fighter action wihout all the nitty gritty technicalities.

Not recommended for grammar nazis until they further proofread and edit the stuff though.
voteText: 37 of 45 people (82%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: This game surprised me in many pleasant ways. The setting is vibrantly colorful, a refreshing change from the industry standard of Medieval Fantasy Europe. The art is beautiful, with excellent character designs and gloriously painted environments. Combat is solid, simple to learn and rewarding to master. The writing is excellent, with good characters and an excellent overarching story. The translation is rough in places, and it has a fair number of crashes. But even when the language barrier reared its ugly head, or a crash knocked me back to the desktop, I found the game's story, characters, and combat were more than enough to keep me loading it right back up again. Also, every time I found a crash or bug, I posted on the discussion boards for the game and received prompt responses from the development team, and they have been unflinchingly professional. As of this moment, I have 24.3 hours of play in this game, and all of that has been in one weekend. I found it impossible to walk away from once I had gotten into it. Though yet unpolished, make no mistake: this game is a gem.
voteText: 25 of 29 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was a Kickstarter backer for Aurion during its campaign but I had heard of and had interest in it for some time beforehand. I backed it in part because the devs, Kiro’o Games, are from Cameroon and basically the whole continent of Africa has practically a nonexistent presence in the industry so I wanted to help out. It also looked good and the game was a clear labor of love, the devs have been making this game for well over a decade and they all taught themselves.

Aurion takes place in a fantasy world inspired by African cultures ranging from Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, and Saharan nations such as Mali and Niger. The two protagonists are the newly crowned and married King and Queen of the peaceful and isolated island nation of Zama, Enzo and Erine Kori-Odan. During their wedding/coronation day Erine’s brother Ngarba invades the city with his army and overthrows his sister and brother-in-law. Now exiles, Enzo and Erine are thrusted into the rest of the world in order to find a way to get their kingdom back.

Aurion is an action RPG more in the vein of JRPGs, it plays like a cross between Tales of Symphonia and a sidescrolling beatemup. You play as Enzo, who’s primary attacks is his sword, but you eventually gain special moves as well as Aurionic Legacies, super modes that grant powerful magical attacks such as Water, Fire, and Darkness through Enzo’s spear. Erine acts as straight mage, teleporting into the battle when you summon her, she can both heal and act as an offensive mage. The combat is fast paced and fun, though perhaps the tutorial could be a bit clearer. (Like I didn’t realize that I could charge my MP until a few hours into the game.) There is also problems with FPS drops, mainly when bosses do their super moves, which can cause you to get hit by them. The ending area also can tank the FPS if you do certain things and can cause the game to crash. Those are things that can be fixed though and aren’t a major detriment.

The writing is similar to the JRPG mold but it’s executed well. Though for the first half of the game the English translation is pretty rough. Kiro’o is Cameroonian so French is their stronger language so the translation starts off janky. For the most part it’s still decipherable, but there’s a lot of grammatical errors and stuff like that. The translation does actually get much better as the game goes on though. Kiroo is also currently working on improving it, so it’s not a deal breaker at all. The setting is also a pretty neat one a nice deviation from the stock Western European fantasy well that games tend to draw from.

While it may not rival the two non-Japanese JRPGs greats currently on Steam, LISA and Undertale, Aurion is still a really nice game well worth playing. Hopefully the game will be a success for Kiro’o because they deserve it after all the years of hard work and dedication.

reviewText:
For lack of a better words to describe what this is, this is a JRPG. It also draws on Shonen genre of manga. It has a structure similar to many of the older japanese RPG games. This is a very vague term to use though, because there are a diverse set of games under that category. Regardless, if you have played that sort of game the gameplay outside combat will be immediately familiar. It even has overworld bits where you walk a tiny sprite between towns.

Finally, I say it is Shonen because it is reminiscent of a certain kind of manga and anime for young males. You pretty much play African Goku. You do not pilot increasingly larger robots but you do sorta gain Stands. Whether that appeals to you or not is a matter of personal preference. If you like badarsery, this game has you covered. Very powerful people perform superhuman feats and have very flashy duels after frankly talking about why they have to fight. A young man discovers himself and his place in the world. Lessons are learned. It is that kind of tale.

The combat is real time and uses a lot of the mechanics of beat-em-ups and fighting games. While stats improve your performance and your equipment provides some benefit, success in combat relies more on execution, especially early on where you aren't basically the strongest being on the planet.

That only tells you what this is, and you might have been able to find this out yourself from this store page. What do I think of this game? Well, I really liked it. Taken as a whole, the game is pretty good.

However, for fans of JRPGs, some of the parts that make up the game may not rate highly when compared to the greats of that genre. Some play JRPGs to master the systems and break the game, some like a good grind for bigger numbers. In these respects, the game is not particularly strong.

The mechanic where you can call in your wife to help you do combos is very cool though. It reminds me a little of Marvel vs Capcom. Unfortunately though, you can't reverse those roles to mix things up, with Erine leading the fighting and Enzo assisting (like you would switch between your 3 characters in MvC). While unfortunate, the assist stuff is really cool on its own. Erine is extremely useful and compliments what Enzo does very well.

But, if you are the sort of person who grinds triple triad cards before getting Ifrit in FF8 you may feel disappointed in that facet of the game. I did not grind once, the fights you end up in just going through the various areas of the game with enemies in it suffices for getting enough power to clear the game.

For me, this was a positive. I prefer to just get on with the game itself rather than worry if my numbers aren't high enough. The game is more than its combat, Like any JRPG worth its salt it has characters, story arcs and an overarching plot that are interesting and tie the entire package together. I feel this is the strongest part of the game. The story and character writing is great. I actually came into this with low expectations for the writing, but I was very impressed. Unlike the combat, I am confident that fans of Shonen manga and anime will enjoy this.

What impressed me most is that the story and characters mesh very well. Each villain is gross in their own way, and have actual reasons for being their particular brand of gross. Each character is easily believable as a product of their era and place in the world. Big political issues are encountered, they are dealt with in a depth I did not expect. The history of the characters and their people is fully explored, from their own actions and guiding philosophies and those of other involved parties, to the material conditions that these spring from. It does this without descending into a morality play. None of it is contrived because it all relates well to the overarching plot, it also serves to give each story arc some flavour. None of the arcs on the way to the conclusion of the plot were weak and forgetable.

It is quite long for a game with little padding, even though the game lacks time sinks like grinding or optional goals and subplots I ended the game at around a days total play time.  I did talk to pretty much every NPC I could, though. The 2d art and animation is pretty decent for a game of this price range, and there is a lot of it. The music matches the art well, however there aren't as many tracks as big budget JRPGs have. I liked the music but each track is used so often that it is hard to really associate them with any specific location and character.

So, to sum this all up, this is a solid debut title from a smallish team, I enjoyed it a lot, warts and all. Well worth a playthrough and the price of admission. It might even end up being my personal GOTY for 2016. Good stuff.

edit: I have removed the first paragraph, on localization, to reflect that the english localization is no longer placeholder.

reviewText:
I heard about this game about a year ago, followed it and then lost track. Suddenly it pops back up on my radar yesterday about 4 hours before release and I'm able to grab it plus the OST(which is awesome by the way!) at the pre-order price! Score right?

YES! Aurion is not only a fun game but a breath of fresh air. The mythology/lore is different from what we usually see and *SPOILERISH* the designs of the outfits are explained in game and make sense! I love little things like that!

True, the dialogue(written) isn't perfect but I can look beyond that seeing as how this is an indie company and English isn't their native language(heck, native English speakers have problems am I right?). The comabt isn't hard to grasp but there's different chains/combos you can make that are pretty cool! I'm not that far into the game but what I have seen is stunning.

I am playing with a Xbox One controller which, when the game first starts, they tell you that the game was actually made to be played with a 360 controller so keep that in mind. Overall I don't regret my purchase and the only reason I stopped playing is because I have to be up in a few hours! Will definitely be recommeding this to friends!

reviewText:
Product received for free

This review is a part of Steamified's Community Reviews program and the credit goes to both Steamified and Kiro'o Games for providing the key for review purposes.
Aurion: Legacy of the Kori-Odan is the Steam debut and a Kickstarter success story from a small Cameroonian-based Kiro'o Games. While most games we see today mostly takes on the European/western mythology, Aurion opts for an African mythology setting and this alone, in my humble opinion, makes this game a must-play title for indie enthusiasts!

The story revolves around the last heir of the Kori-Odan family, Prince Enzo of Zama. On the day of his coronation and marriage to Erine Evou of Soma, the royal palace is attacked by his own brother-in-law Ngarba Rhino" Evou. Defeated and exiled
date: Enzo and Erine embarks on a journey of self-improvement
voteText: carved a path to maturity.\n\nThe African culture and influences are prominent from the start as the inspiration comes directly from their music
votesHelpful: this setting is extremely unique and Kiro'o Games did a splendid job in bringing the African cultures to life! From the amazing soundtracks
votesFunny: depiction of Auriona and even combat stances

You have the standard normal combo which you can chain after doing a Penetrating hit (think of it like a dash with piercing effect) and you can basically juggle your enemy if you're creative enough. The other main point is the Aurionic system. In battle

This is simply amazing since not only it's an eye candy to look at but the move itself is powerful enough to sweep the whole battlefield! This comes with a limitation since using any techniques consumes AP and AP are regenerated by focusing in the heat of battle (pressing down in combat). Erine will help in battle by healing Enzo with her spells so careful planning is needed on how you would utilize every abilities that you possess in combat.\n\nEven with all the praises

reviewText:
**This game was given by the developer for review purposes.**

Over the years video games have taken us almost everywhere, from the distant past to the far future. Because of that, it’s so rare to find a game that has a unique setting, but Aurion: Legacy of the Kori-Odan manages to accomplish that. Aurion is set in Africa, a setting woefully neglected by developers over the years, and as such is quite refreshing to see. Aurion relishes its African roots (the developers are from Cameroon) and creates a believable setting and perhaps most importantly wants you to learn something. Outside of an academic setting it’s rare that a game actually wants to teach you something, take for example Never Alone: a game that teaches you about the history of the Iñupiat people. I would argue that Aurion accomplishes this more so than any other game I’ve played by incorporating the culture and history into the gameplay itself whereas Never Alone simply showed you cutscenes.

The game begins with the player as Enzo, a young king on his wedding day. The nuptials are interrupted when his brother-in-law invades the village and exiles Enzo and his wife Erine from Zama. Now, the game sets up a compelling story and interesting characters but is guilty of an egregious error especially early on: info dump. During the first hour or so you get so many people, places and terms thrown at you that it’s hard to keep track. I’m all for world-building but it definitely could have been done with a more delicate touch instead bludgeoning the player with exposition. This also causes pacing issues and brings game to screech to a halt at times when an NPC is explaining a legend or practice. Yes, I want to know more about a culture but giving me a slideshow and going into great minutia about it is not the most elegant way to go about it. The dev team seemed to be more concerned with telling their culture’s history instead of telling a well-paced story, not that there is anything wrong with that. It’s admirable to be prideful about your history but I do find that it comes at the expense of a good story.

The gameplay is where this title really shines. When exploring the world you have full control over the character and even have some platforming elements involved. Enemies show up on the screen and battle is initiated when they are touched. This brings up the battle interface which is reminiscent of a 2D beat ‘em up. I was honestly shocked by how deep the combat system is, you have two basic attacks as well as “Aurions” which are different fighting styles. You can have four different Aurions available at a time and switch between each seamlessly. This can lead to some deep and rewarding combat that manages to always stay fresh. Add to the fact that there is some verticality to some fights with added platforms and Aurion is more than a competent fighter wrapped in an RPG. Speaking of, all your standard RPG elements are present: leveling up, skills, items to refill HP, and equipment. My one gripe about the RPG elements is that changing equipment does not change the character visually which is a bit disappointing. Got that fancy new sword? You’re still going to see the default sword. It’s not a deal breaker by any means but still bummed me out to see.

Visually, the game looks great. The developers picked a strong artistic direction reminiscent of anime and perhaps intentionally (or not) the animated show The Boondocks. I would definitely say that Enzo and Erine are animated the best and some of the NPC’s can look a little off. Speaking of off, my one request to devs would be to change Enzo’s running. I though it looked terrible and award, like he was about to fall forward onto his face. Aside from the running complaint the visuals look great and have some really nice backdrops.

As far as freshmen efforts go, I think Kiro’o Games should be exceptionally proud of themselves. They have made a game that is not only unquestionably unique but deep and rewarding as well. It’s not without its faults if they can be looked past, there’s a good time to be had here. I should also note that I did not finish the game, I only got about a quarter of the way through so there is easily 20 hours of content here. Here’s hoping that Kiro’o can build upon what they have learned from Aurion. This is definitely a studio to keep your eye on going forward.

reviewText:
So, today (April 16th) the revised English dialogue patch came out for Aurion and I just finished playing through the tutorial. There's still a few mistakes here and there, but it's already a massive improvement over what they started with.

Now that I've been able to understand what the heck the NPCs are saying I'm honestly intrigued by how Auronic warriors do battle, the concept of Aurionic energy, and so on and, yes, I want to keep playing. They still need to work a bit more on the English side of things, but then this is the studio's first game and mistakes are going to be made. The best thing they can do is learn from this and remember their mistakes when/if they make Aurion 2, or any other games in the future. Big lesson from this one: Make sure the script is ready for prime time in ALL the languages it's getting released in, then release the game.

Now that I've been able to sink my teeth in combat is fast paced and fun, using Auronic powers is flashy and very exciting, and I'm definitely liking how Enzo's ultimate technique is basically 'make a giant glowing lion head appear and rawr my enemies to death'.

So yes, now that they've fixed the dialogue issues I can flip that big red thumb back around into a nice cool blue Thumbs Up for Aurion. Just keep up with the dialouge fixes and patching in the future and I think you've got a real winner for your first game.

http://lenwolfgamer.tumblr.com/post/143044814142/aurion-legacy-of-the-kori-odan

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

Dammit.

I spent all week hyped up about this game. Its a fantasy RPG that ISN'T set in Middle Ages Europe, its dripping with African lore (I'm a massive loregeek and mythology geek so that already had me interested), and it promised action combat... but...

Dammit Dammit Dammit...

The dialogue is what did it for me, rather the translation of it. From what I understand, the game's script was originally in French... and I think they got the English version by running the script through Google translate. It comes off as very wooden and doesn't scan well. When the characters talk to each other its like someone trying to speak a language when they don't really know how. There's a lot of really awkward bits of dialogue early on and even a bunch of grammatical errors. Maybe not as big a deal for some, but those thing stand out like neon lights to me.

Really, I just can't recommend it. I wanted to. Oh man I was going on to everyone who'd listen at work about how excited I was to come home and get this game! I wanted to play a fantasy RPG that wasn't about knights and wizards (or anime schoolchildren I guess) and... well, this isn't what I thought it would be at all.

The story could be amazing, but if it's poorly translated it won't matter. I'd imagine the French version of the story is much better but, well, I can't speak or read French! If you can, go for it. If you can't... maybe skip this one until they can hire someone to re-translate the dialogue.

Oh well... at least I'll have Indivisible to look forward to... in about two years.

CLARIFICATION: When I say the dialogue is bad, I mean how it is WRITTEN. I'm not talking about voice acting here guys. In-game text-based dialogue with word bubbles. The translation from French to English is very poor and is very awkward to read at best.

UPDATE: The devs reached out to me (see comments below) and said that they are going to patch the English dialogue next week. I did have a refund request in, but when they said the english dialouge is getting patched I decided to cancel it until after the patch comes through. We'll see if it fixes it or not.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: A copy of the game was provided by Plug In Digital for review purposes but in no way affects our review.

Hello everybody, Shaun Meyers here from Universal Gaming Reviews to bring you a summary of our review for Aurion: Legacy of the Kori-Odan by Kiro'o Games and Plug In Digital. If you'd like to read our full review for the game, you can find it here: https://www.universalgamingreviews.com/aurion-legacy-of-the-kori-odan-overview-and-review/

Aurion is a JRPG inspired action roleplaying game that feels like a mixture of the early Tales games, Street Fighter and a beat 'em up game. The game's combat system has quite a bit to manage and it takes some skill to master everything completely. If you have trouble multitasking then you might have a little trouble getting used to the game's combat but once you do it's a lot of fun.

The game puts you in control of the king of Zama, Enzo Kori-Odan and his wife Erine Evou on a journey of enlightenment and learning after they were exiled by Erine's brother in law in a coup. They meet a wide range of different characters in their journey and the story goes in-depth with the mythology and culture that the game is based on. It explains in detail many different things such as the creation myths and how the Aurion's came to be. It covers a lot of really interesting things and if you enjoy mythology and learning about other cultures as much as mysef, you'll have a lot of fun with this game.

I gave the game our Unmissable award in our full review and I'll be giving the game our recommended award here on Steam. It's a fantastic game and I've been having a great deal of fun with the game so far and I'm excited about seeing how it ends.

Thanks for taking the time to read our summary and full review folks!

-Shaun Meyers (Kyo Akiara) out!

Our Gameplay Video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6sKbg0EAN8k

reviewText: Game is very fun, beautiful and fun to play. reviewText: Kiro'o Games is a new development studio from Africa, which is rare in the modern world, and their first game, Aurion: Legacy of the Kori-Odan, is just as unique in both theming and gameplay. You could oversimply it by saying it's like a cross between Namco's Tales series and retro beat-em-ups, but like all good and worthwhile games, it's greater than the sum of those parts. Sadly, it is rough around the edges, though to be fair, it's in a way you might expect from a handful of developers first setting out to follow their dreams. There are glitches, but the most aggravating ones involve the game not alt-tabbing well, and that can be mitigated by pausing before switching to another window on your desktop. In other words, there's nothing game-breaking, so if you can make it through a game like the original release of Psychonauts, you should make it to the end loving this game too.
voteText: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'll keep it brief:

Pros:

- Setting, by virtue of this alone a unique experience on Steam
- Colourful, vibrant artstyle
- Interesting Husband/Wife dynamic, both in terms of gameplay and narrative
- Combat systems boasts visual flair and packs (quite literally as things progress) quite a punch
- Very cool and impressive anime-esque 'cutscenes' that the game comes hot out the gate with

Cons:

- Dialogue is wooden and marred by spelling/grammatical errors, I assume as a result of translation
- The sheer volume of mechanics/systems you need to keep track of, presented by not always so clear tutorials
- Feels at times like frames of animation are missing during combat, not as smooth/fluid as it could've been

Overall, the experience I've had so far has been more or less enjoyable. Action elements of the game, while not perfect, certainly do their job well. The story is interesting enough thanks to the influence of African mythology, but certainly the issues with translated dialogue hold it back in places. And lastly, but perhaps most importantly, Erine (the MC's wife) is totally cute. Give it a go.

reviewText:
I'll update this review as i get more game time in + proper review video will follow.

My short of it is so far:
+ Setting: African myths and idea's? Yes please - This is a setting thats used WAY TO LITTLE in gaming and deserves all the love it can get
+ Artstyle is amazing and i mean AMAZING. it looks fantastic in terms of aesthetic.
+ 2D Brawler combat is tight and controls great
+ First ~hour of story is FANTASTIC.
+ performance is fine (GTX 780)

- Really needs Controller. KB&M Controls are sub par.
- Very linear. Story is GREAT, but replayability is very low / non-existent

a game I highly recommend   :)

reviewText:
Product received for free

**The game was given to me by the developer**

The Music and the Art style are definitely really unique, its kinda like the western version of a Vanillaware game, but what definitely caught my eye the most so far were the gameplay mechanics. The way the game flows once you start the tutorial where you get the ability to Dash/Dodge cancel, then it gets even better once you start getting more skills to make some really neat combos.

Bosses are interesting and challenging cause even though you can combo them, they have ways to escape combos and counterattack what you do, definitely making sure that you need to know what you are doing in order to fight against them effectively, chasing them down after they escape, using charge attacks to break their guard, launch them in the air for quick effective combos, etc.

I haven't gotten too far yet for the story to develop a lot, but so far I would definitely say the game is fun enough to warrant purchase on the gameplay alone. Definitely recommend it so far.

-Omega

reviewText:
I've been playing this for the last couple of days, after having seen it's Kickstarter a year back. I also got to try it at PAX East and met the lead programmer, Guillaume Olivier. When he told me it was already available on steam, I got it that night. I've been streaming it on my YouTube channel and enjoying it every time.

If you are looking for an action RPG with a unique fantasy style, this is certainly one to get your hands on.

Pros:
-Unique style of art
-Interesting story
-Fun combat action
-Very versitile fighting system

Cons:
-The load times are a little long
-At this time, there are still a few typos in the english translation, but that will most likely be ironed out later.
-The story opens only a little slower than I'd normally like, but it makes up for it as you progress.

All in all, I'd certainly recommend the game, and already shared my praise with a few of my close friends before it was even released.

DO NOT expect it to be a new Final Fantasy or Phantasy Star. It's more comperable to Castlevania's GBA titles with a better combat system, but instanced battles. It has some platforming, but it's not too complicated for standard RPG only" gamers. Some of the early attacks are kinda weak
date: but attacks like Shaka's Wrath and your Ulimate are incredibly satisfying.\n\nIn all
voteText: it might just unchain your inner Aurionic!"
